comments.commentBody:
Martin, Will came through for my final and reveal of my meta-avatar theme, which has been running since Thanksgiving.

Favorite (LOL) fill forever: GOBITWEEN. And he was that as well. But that is not the entry for the avatar connection.

If my observations are correct, Israelis are fairly united in their aim and purpose to blame the Palestinians on every count. It is never the fault of Israel.
The only solution is a Single State for the Holy lands and with a Jeffersonian Democracy, one person one vote and live with it, my friends.

Would you trust the Israeli's ? I wouldn't trust Livni either. The deal has to be done in totality or nothing. Livni and Bibi are for greater Israel don't believe her story. The 3% of the
west bank that Israel claims it must have snakes through the west bank and surrounds East Jerusalem. It creates a dysfunctional Palestine
As Tom Friedman has said on a number of occasions, "The Palestinians never miss an opportunity...to miss an opportunity."

Excellent column. I respect Ms. Livni and hope that her influence in Israel and the region continues to grow. Her views on the West Bank settlements and a two state solution appear pragmatic and nuanced.

It is tragic that numerous efforts to reach an Israeli-Palestinian accord have been unavailing. If this account is correct, Mr. Abbas has missed an important opportunity. It would be interesting, as well, to hear the view of the Abbas team as to why the 2014 negotiations broke down.

Another observation: from the admittedly little that I've seen, it appears to me that the negotiating style of the Middle East is one of brinksmanship. In the U.S., one can typically rely on the agreements reached at the start of negotiations, with additional points agreed to in successive rounds until a final agreement is consummated. Middle Eastern negotiators, however, seem to take already-negotiated terms as mere suggestions, with either or both of the parties reserving the right to renege and walk out at any time prior to signing final documents. If my observations are correct, it's little wonder that an Israeli-Palestian peace accord remains unconsummated.
So Facebook is experimenting with ways of getting more money in politics and blocking anti-govt protests in Russia. The Axis of Evil: Iran, No Korea and Facebook.
Now if only Facebook could put ads on our Congress's Facebook pages to encourage them to work for the good of the people, we might actually get through to them.  Hey, whatever works.

FB continues to more 'carefully' decide what 'is best for' my News Feed although it never quite discloses the algorithm for this (sound familiar?).

So it stands to reason that 'what's best for me' is based on who's willing to pay the most for access to that News Feed. What they don't get through their heads is the principle of self-selection, as in "away from FB entirely."

The more things change...
Now North Korea will blame Sony for caving in to international pressure in releasing the movie:) Crazy world.
I can only pray that food writers NEVER become interested in liver.

I tried using the NYT Chronicle page to determine the frequency of words I thought would be fairly common - political, economy, social. What happened in 2013? See chart below.

http://chronicle.nytlabs.com/?keyword=economy.political.social

A dozen eggs--which provides a week's worth of breakfasts--is still cheaper than one fast food meal, with fries and a soda.  Just refuse to buy the expensive stuff and let the Free Market do its job: eventually the prices will come down.

American food prices are NOT high.  A friend from China had her cell out to take pictures in supermarkets of the variety and PRICES which are much lower than in China (while the average income is much lower in China).  She sent those pictures to her friends, who were amazed at the lower prices and great variety in our grocery stores.
Am I the only one that wonders why food prices are so high?  It's killing most American's.

I couldn't agree more.  I've been a Kaiser member for more than 50 years in southern California.  In the early years, some of the horror stories were true, but in the past 20 years, they have made great strides in achieving the highest rankings for health care providers in California.  They will actually pursue you to keep appointments and make sure than you're taking prescribed medications.  They really do believe in the health maintenance part of the HMO name.  And, prices are better than comparable PPOs.

That may well be true, but if you're in an area that offers Kaiser Permanente, you have only yourself to blame.  Kaiser offers tops tier care at very competitive prices.  No shortage of doctors or specialists, and they really do believe in health maintenance.

Re the latest decision to screen The Interview, how about this - it was all a ploy by Sony to increase viewership.  After all, EW proclaimed before the brouhaha that Sony would have to pledge to dunk an employee in a vat of water for each ticket sold to see the movie.
Very few know the connection between Sony and rootkit. Sony intentionally inserted rootkit into customers PCs a few years back disguised as a music CD.

You say that as if it is a bad thing.  Some of us don't agree.  There is a line from the Tao Te Ching that goes, "Ruling a large country is like cooking a small fish."  The implication is that too much handling ruins a small fish ...  and a large country.

This is not reality Carlos. Believe me. You will never se the news article, but that 5% number is a fabrication. NOTHING in the fundamentals of our economics has improved in 15 years. We have an economy based on consumerism. Inflation numbers that don't include food or fuel. Unemployment numbers that look better when people take a low paying part-time job or give up altogether. We have a national debt that is too big to ever pay back, even if we actually had 5% GDP growth for an extended time period. Not to mention our clout an influence on the world is at an all-time low and getting worse. It is late evening in America and we have an ugly night to get through before we see better times for real.
Oh don't you believe they aren't spending money. They've been working to hide the fact that the US National Debt went up by a trillion Dollars in November, Google it.

Have you looked at the data on the Bureau of Labor Statistics Web site?  There are a host of tables and graphs you can get there.  Look up the civilian labor force participation rate.  We are not at March 1978 levels.  The CLFPR has declined, year over year, every month since Obama took office ... except one, which was last month and the number broke even.  Other numbers you need to see for yourself, like the full- and part-time employment figures.  What you offered is DNC talking points.  The BLS site offers facts.  They don't match the rosy picture of the DNC and the White House.

Rev. Camarena,
Your problem is that I'm not an ideologue. I follow the numbers where they lead. I'm paid to give accurate results. I'll even give people who pay me what they don't want, when it is bad news. I know I'll be proven right because the numbers don't lie. You can make them into lies, but the facts remain, and in the end reality wins. The longer you deny reality, the worse the consequences are likely to be, when reality catches up to you.

I'm an independent.  I don't have any horse in the race other than my job, which is constructing computer models, and recently constructing computer models of the economy.  If I have a political creed, it is this (assuming you can call it a creed): No pure ideological system ever works given time.  This is particularly true of economic systems.  If you try to keep your economic system "pure" anything, it is going to crash on you.
Yes, that's it.  "...short lifetime" as in, "untimely cut short."  Yikes.
How long, if ever, before the rest of Americas gets your point? Cant be too soon!

Once again, just a few weeks ago, the pundits were predicting a market correction downward. And then, as always happens at Year-End, they come out of the woodwork, predicting the DOs and DON'Ts for the coming year. The real DO, is don't listen to them. They are mostly looking for notoriety, and filling print-space and air time. Do your own homework.

http://thetruthoncommonsense.com
Get a dog? That is your advice to the long-term unemployed? I thought you were well-intentioned until you made that flip remark.

Hopefully, if an unemployed person lives in the half of the US in a state which offers Medicaid benefits to those earning under a certain income -- he or she will be eligible for that kind of insurance.  It's not the best, but it's a lot, lot better than no insurance at all.  To extend job-related insurance with the COBRA law is all but unaffordable for most of the unemployed.

My husband was laid off in 2008, from a job he worked at for 28 years. He was 54. He applied for at least 100 jobs, even jobs paying minimum wage. Three and a half years ago, he was hired…but had to move, only home from Friday night until Sunday afternoon. During his time being unemployed, he became depressed. He sat in front of the TV. This study is a no brainer. Of course, when you have worked your whole life, then tossed out like an old shoe, you get depressed. He is now back home, working, at age 60. My heart goes out to those, not able to find a job. So horrible for him, me and out teenage son. Wishing all of those unemployed, a job.
